definitions.definition: The state or quality of being written in the same way, especially when spelled with the same letters (as with a pair of homonyms ), or also as represented with similar or identical glyphs (as with homoglyphs ); the state or quality of existing as homographs .
An isomorphism between projective spaces that maps straight lines to straight lines.
examples: A homography on a real projective plane can be specified by a mapping from one set of four non-collinear points to another set of four non-collinear points. Given such a specification, then the 3-by-3 homography matrix may be computed by means of the DLT (Direct Linear Transformation) algorithm.

main_definition: The state or quality of being written in the same way, especially when spelled with the same letters (as with a pair of homonyms ), or also as represented with similar or identical glyphs (as with homoglyphs ); the state or quality of existing as homographs .
secondary_definitions: ( geometry ) An isomorphism between projective spaces that maps straight lines to straight lines.
